hints_html: Can you first isolate X in the equation before doing any matrix manipulation?
hints_latex:
Can you first isolate \emph{X} in the equation before doing any matrix
manipulation?
hints_raw: Can you first isolate ''X'' in the equation before doing any matrix manipulation?
sols_html:
We first carry out operations to isolate X

\[\begin{aligned} A + (BX)^T &= C\\ (BX)^T &= C - A\\ ((BX)^T)^T &= (C-A)^T\\ BX &= (C-A)^T\\ B^{-1}BX &= B^{-1}(C-A)^T\\ X &= B^{-1}(C-A)^T\end{aligned}\]

We now simply compute \((C-A)^T\) and \(B^{-1}\) and multiply them together.

\((C-A)^T\):

\[\begin{aligned} \left(\left[\begin{array}{ccc} -1 & 9 & 0 \\ 3 & 7 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 2 \end{array}\right] \quad -\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 2 & 1 & 0 \\ 3 & 5 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array}\right] \quad \right)^T &= \left(\left[ \begin{array}{cccc} -3 & 8 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\\ \end{array} \right] \right)^T \\ &= \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} -3 & 0 & 0 \\ 8 & 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\\ \end{array} \right] \end{aligned}\]

We can invert B by using an extended matrix and doing the following:

\[\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{array}{cccccc} 0 & -5 & 1 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ -3 & 7 & -1 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 1 & -1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right] &\sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccccc} 0 & -5 & 1 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 4 & -1 & 0 & 1 & 3 \\ 1 & -1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right] \\ &\sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccccc} 0 & -5 & 1 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -3 \\ 1 & -1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right]\\ & \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccccc} 0 & 0 & 1 & -4 & -5 & -15 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -3 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -2 \end{array} \right]\\ & \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccccc} 1 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -2 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -3 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & -4 & -5 & -15 \end{array} \right] \end{aligned}\]

So

\(B^{-1} = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} -1 & -1 & -2 \\ -1 & -1 & -3 \\ -4 & -5 & -15 \end{array} \right]\)

You are then left with multiplying the two matrices out, which gives the final result of:

\(\left[ \begin{array}{cccc} -5 & -2 & -2 \\ -5 & -2 & -3 \\ -28 & -10 & -15\\ \end{array} \right]\)
sols_latex:
We first carry out operations to isolate \emph{X}

\begin{align*}
A + (BX)^T &= C\\
(BX)^T &= C - A\\
((BX)^T)^T &= (C-A)^T\\
BX &= (C-A)^T\\
B^{-1}BX &= B^{-1}(C-A)^T\\
X &= B^{-1}(C-A)^T
\end{align*}

We now simply compute $(C-A)^T$ and $B^{-1}$ and multiply them together.

$(C-A)^T$:

\begin{align*}
\left(\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
-1 & 9 & 0 \\ 3 & 7 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 2
\end{array}\right] \quad
-\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 1 & 0 \\ 3 & 5 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right] \quad \right)^T  &= \left(\left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
-3 & 8 & 0 \\ 
0 & 2 & 0 \\ 
0 & 0 & 1\\ 
\end{array} \right] \right)^T \\
&= \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
-3 & 0 & 0 \\ 
8 & 2 & 0 \\ 
0 & 0 & 1\\ 
\end{array} \right] 
\end{align*}

We can invert \emph{B} by using an extended matrix and doing the
following:

\begin{align*}
\left[ \begin{array}{cccccc}
0 & -5 & 1 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 
-3 & 7 & -1 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 
1 & -1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 
\end{array} \right] &\sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccccc}
0 & -5 & 1 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 
0 & 4 & -1 & 0 & 1 & 3 \\ 
1 & -1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 
\end{array} \right] \\
&\sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccccc}
0 & -5 & 1 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 
0 & 1 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -3 \\ 
1 & -1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 
\end{array} \right]\\
& \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccccc}
0 & 0 & 1 & -4 & -5 & -15 \\ 
0 & 1 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -3 \\ 
1 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -2 
\end{array} \right]\\
& \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccccc}
1 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -2 \\
0 & 1 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -3 \\ 
0 & 0 & 1 & -4 & -5 & -15  
\end{array} \right] 
\end{align*}

So

$B^{-1} = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
 -1 & -1 & -2 \\
 -1 & -1 & -3 \\ 
 -4 & -5 & -15  
\end{array} \right]$

You are then left with multiplying the two matrices out, which gives the
final result of:

$\left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
-5 & -2 & -2 \\ 
-5 & -2 & -3 \\ 
-28 & -10 & -15\\ 
\end{array} \right]$
sols_raw:
We first carry out operations to isolate ''X''

<math> 
\begin{align}
A + (BX)^T &= C\\
(BX)^T &= C - A\\
((BX)^T)^T &= (C-A)^T\\
BX &= (C-A)^T\\
B^{-1}BX &= B^{-1}(C-A)^T\\
X &= B^{-1}(C-A)^T
\end{align}
</math>

We now simply compute <math> (C-A)^T</math> and <math> B^{-1}</math> and multiply them together.

<math> (C-A)^T</math>: 

<math>
\begin{align}
\left(\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
-1 & 9 & 0 \\ 3 & 7 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 2
\end{array}\right] \quad
-\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 1 & 0 \\ 3 & 5 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right] \quad \right)^T  &= \left(\left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
-3 & 8 & 0 \\ 
0 & 2 & 0 \\ 
0 & 0 & 1\\ 
\end{array} \right] \right)^T \\
&= \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
-3 & 0 & 0 \\ 
8 & 2 & 0 \\ 
0 & 0 & 1\\ 
\end{array} \right] 
\end{align}
</math>

We can invert ''B'' by using an extended matrix and doing the following:

<math> 
\begin{align}
\left[ \begin{array}{cccccc}
0 & -5 & 1 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 
-3 & 7 & -1 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 
1 & -1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 
\end{array} \right] &\sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccccc}
0 & -5 & 1 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 
0 & 4 & -1 & 0 & 1 & 3 \\ 
1 & -1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 
\end{array} \right] \\
&\sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccccc}
0 & -5 & 1 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 
0 & 1 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -3 \\ 
1 & -1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 
\end{array} \right]\\
& \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccccc}
0 & 0 & 1 & -4 & -5 & -15 \\ 
0 & 1 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -3 \\ 
1 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -2 
\end{array} \right]\\
& \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccccc}
1 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -2 \\
0 & 1 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -3 \\ 
0 & 0 & 1 & -4 & -5 & -15  
\end{array} \right] 
\end{align}
</math>

So 

<math>B^{-1} = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
 -1 & -1 & -2 \\
 -1 & -1 & -3 \\ 
 -4 & -5 & -15  
\end{array} \right] </math>

You are then left with multiplying the two matrices out, which gives the final result of:

<math> \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
-5 & -2 & -2 \\ 
-5 & -2 & -3 \\ 
-28 & -10 & -15\\ 
\end{array} \right] </math>
statement_html:
Solve for the matrix X if

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A + (BX)^T = C,\end{aligned}\]

where

\(A = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 2 & 1 & 0 \\ 3 & 5 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array}\right], \quad B = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 0 & -5 & 1 \\ -3 & 7 & -1 \\ 1 & -1 & 0 \end{array}\right], \quad C = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} -1 & 9 & 0 \\ 3 & 7 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 2 \end{array}\right].\)
statement_latex:
Solve for the matrix \emph{X} if

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
A + (BX)^T = C,
\end{align*} where

$A = \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 1 & 0 \\ 3 & 5 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right], \quad
B = \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & -5 & 1 \\ -3 & 7 & -1 \\ 1 & -1 & 0
\end{array}\right], \quad
C = \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
-1 & 9 & 0 \\ 3 & 7 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 2
\end{array}\right].$
statement_raw:
Solve for the matrix ''X'' if

:<math> \displaystyle
A + (BX)^T = C,
</math>
where

<math>
A = \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 1 & 0 \\ 3 & 5 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right], \quad
B = \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & -5 & 1 \\ -3 & 7 & -1 \\ 1 & -1 & 0
\end{array}\right], \quad
C = \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
-1 & 9 & 0 \\ 3 & 7 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 2
\end{array}\right].
</math>
